sense.name: misplace some concrete thing, be unable to account or track something or someone
sense.commentary: Note: it is assumed the thing or person is desired to be found or recovered.
sense.examples: She lost her purse when she left it unattended on her seat. I've lost my car keys for the third time this week! He thinks he may have lost his glasses at the gym. The cops lost him again as he snuck around the back of the building.

sense.name: not succeed in achieving some abstract thing
sense.examples: The Red Sox have lost the last five games. He lost custody of his son. I lost the opportunity to spend a year abroad. She lost her son's respect by lying to him.

sense.name: to attempt communication that is missing clarity or accuracy.
sense.commentary: Note: Also, to be unable to discern or perceive something (see the last two examples)
sense.examples: I am losing you with this bad phone connection. I think the film 'Portrait of a Lady' completely lost what Henry James had in mind. He'll lose the marketing department with these technical slides. He lost the forest for the trees. I lost the clarinet theme through the complicated instrumentation.

sense.name: relinquish something physical or emotional, usually involuntarily
sense.commentary: Includes: LOSE WEIGHT, LOSE ONE'S TEMPER, LOSE IT (as in losing control)
sense.examples: He lost his life on 9/11. She lost her husband to that woman from Washington. He lost a finger in the boating accident. She lost her voice before the Met auditions. Your pestering is making me lose my temper! Pancho lost weight before the big cruise. When my cousin started cursing at my mom, I lost it.

sense.name: to recede, fade away or fall off
sense.examples: I was losing the shape of the distant skyline through the fog. France is losing its tradition of classic cooking to the fast food industry. She lost fifteen pounds last summer. Those old customs have been lost to history. I've lost my appetite. Let's lose him!
